Question_1.Context: The paper discusses the use of calcium fluoride (CaF2) for biomedical applications.
Question_1.Question: What is the main reason for using CaF2 in biomedical applications?
Question_1.Source: CaF2 nanopowders are extensively used for biomedical applications like imaging due to its high stability and brilliant luminescent properties.

Question_2.Context: The paper discusses different coating methods for metal implants.
Question_2.Question: Which coating method provides denser coatings according to the text?
Question_2.Source: Coating methods like sputtering, plasma spray, and pulsed laser deposition give thin film coatings, whereas dip-coating and electrophoretic coatings gave comparatively denser coatings.

Question_3.Context: The paper mentions the use of CaF2 as a theranostic agent.
Question_3.Question: What is the main characteristic of theranostic agents?
Question_3.C: Used for both therapy and diagnosis
Question_3.Source: Theranostic agents are materials which can be used as a combination for therapy and diagnosis.

Question_4.Context: The paper discusses the preparation of a new type of bioactive glass.
Question_4.Question: What happens when the newly prepared bioactive glasses are immersed in simulated body fluid?
Question_4.B: They form a biocompatible hydroxyapatite layer
Question_4.Source: When the newly prepared bioactive glasses are immersed in static simulated body fluid, a complete biocompatible hydroxyapatite layer formed on the glass surface within a period of 3 weeks.

Question_5.Context: The paper discusses the dip-coating process for depositing CaF2 sols onto borosilicate glasses.
Question_5.Question: What is the main drawback associated with the dip-coating process for dental applications?
Question_5.Source: These coatings reported to have a drawback of poor adhesion characteristics.

Question_6.Context: The paper describes the preparation of a CaF2 solution for dip coating.
Question_6.Question: What was used to prepare the CaF2 solution for dip coating?
Question_6.Source: The CaF2 solution for dip coating was prepared using ethanol (99.99% purity), glycerin, and CaF2 nanopowders.

Question_7.Context: The paper discusses the mechanical properties of the CaF2-coated samples.
Question_7.Question: What is the adhesion strength between the CaF2 thin film and the base substrate?
Question_7.Source: The adhesion strength between CaF2 thin film and the base substrate was measured to be 3MPa.

Question_8.Context: The paper discusses the dissolution behavior of CaF2 in simulated body fluid.
Question_8.Question: What happens to the dissolution rate of Ca ions in the SBF over time?
Question_8.Source: The dissolution rate of both Ca and F ions is almost constant over a period of 4 weeks.

Question_9.Context: The paper discusses the cell viability study of the CaF2-coated samples.
Question_9.Question: What is the main conclusion regarding the cell viability of the coated samples?
Question_9.Source: At the same time, it is also seen that with 50% extract dilution when mixed with 50% DMEM, the cell viability is ~80% which is acceptable by ISO 10993-5 standards.

Question_10.Context: The paper discusses the corrosion behavior of the CaF2-coated samples.
Question_10.Question: What is the main advantage of a CaF2-coated sample in terms of corrosion resistance?
Question_10.Source: From Fig. 6, it is clear that a CaF2-coated sample have better resistance to the accelerated corrosion.
